unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about vegetable shopping. It's funny, I never thought much about it until I moved out of my parents' house in Delhi and had to do it myself. Now, it's like a weekly adventure.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about vegetable shopping. It's funny, I never thought much about it until I moved out of my parents' house in Delhi and had to do it myself. Now, it's like a weekly adventure.

unnormalised: My first shock was the sheer *quantity* everything is sold in. My mom would always buy things in these vague amounts, like "a little bit of that" or "enough for one sabzi". Now I'm facing down vendors going, "Okay beta, how many *kilos* of onions do you want?". I'm thinking, "Kilos? I just need like, 3-4 onions for my daal!". I learned pretty quickly that " पाव भर " (250 gms) is my go-to measurement for most things.
normalised: My first shock was the sheer quantity everything is sold in. My mom would always buy things in these vague amounts, like "a little bit of that" or "enough for one sabzi". Now I'm facing down vendors going, "Okay beta, how many kilograms of onions do you want?". I'm thinking, "Kilos? I just need like, three to four onions for my daal!". I learned pretty quickly that "pav bhar" (two hundred and fifty grams) is my go to measurement for most things.

unnormalised: And the prices! I remember getting so annoyed when I was younger and my mom would haggle over every rupee. Now I understand. You can literally walk 10 feet down the street and find tomatoes for Rs. 20/kg at one stall and Rs. 25/kg at another. I even saw one guy trying to sell them for Rs 30/kg! It's madness. Now I carry my reusable cloth bags and have my bargaining face on.
normalised: And the prices! I remember getting so annoyed when I was younger and my mom would haggle over every rupee. Now I understand. You can literally walk ten feet down the street and find tomatoes for rupees twenty per kilogram at one stall and rupees twenty five per kilogram at another. I even saw one guy trying to sell them for rupees thirty per kilogram! It's madness. Now I carry my reusable cloth bags and have my bargaining face on.

unnormalised: Then there are the different units they use for different things. Greens like palak or methi are sold by the bunch (gaddi), but what one person considers a “gaddi” can vary wildly. One gaddi can be 100 gms while the other gaddi can be 200 gms. Rice and pulses are sold in kilograms (kg) usually, while some spices are sold in grams. Trying to convert everything in my head on the fly is a workout! I still make mistakes and either end up with way too much of something or have to run back to the store halfway through cooking. Once I ended up buying 2 kgs of ginger because I didn't specify how little I wanted! I still have ginger chutney in the fridge.
normalised: Then there are the different units they use for different things. Greens like palak or methi are sold by the bunch (gaddi), but what one person considers a "gaddi" can vary wildly. One gaddi can be one hundred grams while the other gaddi can be two hundred grams. Rice and pulses are sold in kilograms (k-g) usually, while some spices are sold in grams. Trying to convert everything in my head on the fly is a workout! I still make mistakes and either end up with way too much of something or have to run back to the store halfway through cooking. Once I ended up buying two kilograms of ginger because I didn't specify how little I wanted! I still have ginger chutney in the fridge.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the different weighing scales. The guy in the local kirana store still uses those old-school balance scales with weights. Very nostalgic, but I'm never quite sure if I'm getting an accurate measure. Then you have the electronic scales that are supposedly more precise, but who knows if they're calibrated correctly? At one place you might get 250 gms of tomatoes while it can be 300 gms in another store.

At one place you might get two hundred and fifty grams of tomatoes while it can be three hundred grams in another store.

unnormalised: Also the size matters. I bought 1 dozen bananas, and these bananas are small. Not the same as the big bananas from my supermarket which might be 8 inches long, so I should have specified that I wanted "big bananas".
normalised: Also the size matters. I bought one dozen bananas, and these bananas are small. Not the same as the big bananas from my supermarket which might be eight inches long, so I should have specified that I wanted "big bananas".

unnormalised: Lastly, freshness. You can't just buy things blindly. You have to poke and prod and sniff. If the coriander looks like it's lost half its weight since yesterday (and they charged you as if it hasn’t), you walk away. My grandmother taught me well; that skill saved me lots of money.
normalised: Lastly, freshness. You can't just buy things blindly. You have to poke and prod and sniff. If the coriander looks like it's lost half its weight since yesterday (and they charged you as if it hasn’t), you walk away. My grandmother taught me well; that skill saved me lots of money.

unnormalised: So yeah, vegetable shopping is a learning curve. But hey, at least I'm getting some fresh air and exercise, and I'm supporting local businesses. Plus, I'm slowly becoming an expert at judging the weight and quality of vegetables with just a glance. Maybe I should start my own vegetable stand…
